column3: Germany;Weissbier - Hefeweizen;Klosterbrauerei Andechs;"One of the most balance ""Hefeweizen"" beers i have drink.. All here is amazing balance and awesome.. Nothing can affect you to not enjoy this beer.. First of all the taste is great like some other classic ""Hefeweizen"" beers but with little less spiciness.. This beer is little more on ""Franziskaner hefe"" beer but with little less sweetness and spiciness but definitely more soft than ""Paulaner"".. The body is medium and the carbonation is little high but its ok.. In fact the carbonation push the beer in your stomach very smooth.. Also is little watery and that make it dangerous drinkable.. Overall the most balance ""HefeWeizen"" beer i have drink today and after ""Franziskaner"" my second favorite of the style.. All here is great and very refreshing.."

column3: Canada;Bock - Dunkler Bock;Denisons Brewing Co. (Victoria St.);YUMMMY Bock!!! Mike does it again!!!! It is impossible to have a bad beer here. This beer is another increadibly wonderful offering by the Denison''s Brewery. Big malt character with Vienna malt coming through in droves. It is more heavily hopped than the classics and I like this a lot as it give this resounding play with the malt and hops that you only find in rare beers although it is common from this brewer. Denisons is a required stop for any Rate Beerian

column3: Germany;Low Alcohol - Wheat;Bayerische Staatsbrauerei Weihenstephan;12 ounce bottle A passable low alcohol release isn't going to stand out from anything with more than a percent of alcohol. This typical low alcohol release does however contain enough flavor to more than a two sip and down the drain offering. If you find a cheap bottle it might be worth a try to warm up the palate before you dive into other stuff. AROMA / APPEARANCE Banana cloves
column4: nutty malts
column5: and cool toast feel lean but still inviting. The bronze flat base adds little visual interest yet looks average below its creamy white head. FLAVOR / PALATE Watered down marmalade rinses the palate clean before it slowly fades into obscurity. Bubbly banana chips pairs with apple juice to leave a simulacrum of what a wheat ale might be if you thinned it down. By the end it fizzles into a dull distraction. As long as you have the appropriate expectations it delivers on its promise.

The aroma is floral and caramel. The floral hops come to the front in the flavor and are weird. The palate is bitter. Not a good brew from FFF. (Floydicus informed me that this was last brewed 4 years ago. It is likely past it’s prime).

column2: Netherlands;Belgian Ale - Strong Pale;Brouwerij 't IJ (Duvel Moortgat);In een BeerBattle hebben we 't IJ Columbus het laten opnemen tegen de Hop Ruiter van de Scheldebrouwerij. Daarbij moest Columbus het onderspit delven. De combinatie van veel hop en veel alcohol is het 'unique selling point' van de Columbus. In de geur komt deze hoeveelheid hop licht terug. Wat het bier ook mee heeft zijn de 'looks' een mooie amberkleur met creme schuimkraag die helaas snel wegzakt. Wat de smaak betreft heeft het flesje mogelijk wat te lang gestaan. Er zit een wat sloffige smaak op. Het gevoel op de tong is prettig. In z'n algemeen had ik er iets meer van verwacht.

column2: Austria;Bock - Doppelbock;Brauerei Schloss Eggenberg;"Wow that was very strong experience.. This beer (if we can call it a beer because seems more like liquid) is really strong.. I can feel the fire in my mouth and in my stomach right now.. Remind you some ""Belgian"" strong quad like the ""Rochefort 10"". When you have the first mouthfeel the flavor and the strong alcohol numb your tongue like the ""Rochefort 10"".. On the other hand the taste is very sweet and pleasant and also the aftertaste that you can notice very well the caramel.. Overall is a decent beer despite the high alcohol that is very noticeable and perhaps make you problems if you are not have full stomach.. Otherwise is like you drink one high quality ""Quadrupel Belgian Beer"".. ""Austria"" must be proud to have such a decent beer."

column3: United States;Bock - Dunkler Bock;Stoudts Brewing Co.;750 ml bottle Thanks to Jeff for sharing this at a winter tasting. It was a 2004 vintage and it shows as this beer has seen better days. I would loved to have tried it in its prime. It is far from the worst beer at the moment but everything seems to be a mere shadow of what it was at one point. It reminds me of trying an year old imperial IPA which is beginning the slow decline to mediocrity. Aroma / Appearance - Thin and watery the body had almost no head despite a vigorous pour. Chocolate brownies and black cherry stick out the most as the hops have long since given up the ghost. They still haunt the edges of the senses from time to time. Flavor / Palate - Thin this is beginning to develop a bit of dryness. Despite the bottle conditioning it shows signs of a beer on the decline. Overall it has held up admirably for almost six years but is a perfect example of why only a handful of styles should be aged for such periods of time. If you are crazy enough to still be aging one either drink it now or stick it in the back of the cellar as a decoration.

column3: England;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;Oakham Ales;A Mes rate: cask at Baker St Sporks Gorgeous clean pale gold with a thin white head and easily the best condition I have had in this place. Stunning aroma that is incredibly Belgian. Assertive hops

The flavour is not quite in the same league. The biscuit malt comes right to the front and drowns out the hops just a bit too much. That said the bitter finish has excellent length and leaves me yearning for more. Not their best but still bloody good stuff from Oakham.

column3: United States;Pale Ale - American / APA;Willoughby Brewing Co.;"On tap at brewpub This was on the board of ""micro batches"" as Lost Nation Pale Ale dry hopped with Target hops. To see what that was like I ordered a small sample. It turned out to be pretty solid. I’ll have to try the regular version at some point but based on this I would classify this beer as an underpowered IPA. Aroma / Appearance - Resiny hops are evident but not overpowering. A light woodiness accents this well. The body was a carbonated mandarin orange with little head. Flavor / Palate - I had to let this one warm for a while but eventually it was no longer ice cold. When I did give it a try I picked up a slight resiny woody taste (as if an IPA had been diluted just a bit or not made as strongly). The fluid mouthfeel was balanced enough to leave to only a temporary bitterness in the throat. This was sessionable and enjoyable though I would probably opt for the regular non-dry hopped version if I order it again."

At full price I would have still get one depending on the rest of the offerings at the time. This meets all the classic requirements of a dry stout so if that is your thing give it a try. Aroma / Appearance - A dense one finger head was shaved down as I watched from my seat at the bar. When it got to me about half was left protecting a black fluid body. Rye toast
column4: oatmeal
column5: and a hint of ash melded cleanly and simply. The trace sweetness was hard to pin down precisely. Flavor / Palate - Just a trace too watery the mouthfeel is still flavorful. Cooled firewood left over from a bonfire mixed with chocolate flakes and delicate hops to sweep across the tongue. Fading at a sedate pace it left hints behind but not much more. I would definitely order this again if I were at Willoughby more often.

column3: United States;IPA;Arcadia Brewing Company;Poured into a becher pint glass
column4: the appearance was a semi-hazy golden color with a finger and a half’s worth of white frothy head. Sly lace. The aroma had a bright citrusy hop burst over some earthy hop bitterness. Light leafy dryness with a little bit of floral to herbal character. The flavor dryly leaned towards the sweet side in a malty sort of way. Hop tones seem a bit dispersed to allow the malt base become a bit sturdier and run throughout the aftertaste. Slight malty sort of finish. The feel was almost medium bodied with a good carbonation about it. ABV felt as appropriate. Fairly smooth along my tongue. Overall
column5: seemed more of an English styled IPA to me and came across pretty clean and would be well done if that’s what Arcadia intended.

Canada;Malt Liquor;Great Western Brewing (Canadian Brewing);"Swill. Dumped in to glass. Made lots of rocky white foam which died shortly after. Standard lager gold with ok effervecance. This crap is teetering between horrid swill and acceptable swill. DRINK IT COLD AND QUICKLY!! Aroma comes across early on as low quality stinky malts and such but does gain a bit more of a sweetness within minutes of the pour but still maintains that poor mix of both. Nothing too offending though. As for the taste - grain and malts
column4: sweetness and obvious alcohol on every chug. Most sips are decent enough but then you get hit by the alcohol. Leaves an unpleasant taste in the mouth. Light medium bodied with a thick viscous impression in the aftertaste. Notable bitterness
column5: especially mid-sip. Excessive alcohol taste. This stuff is made for people who look for pennies in conveniece store parking lots to chug ice cold and then puke after funnelling 12 cans in 19 seconds. I’m slamming it so hard because the description at the top of this page claim ""GOLD medal winner in the Midwest Brewer’s Festival
column7: ok then. Maybe it’s only competitor was a can of varsol. To rate this really bad is probally an injustice. I recommend to myself that I have a swill-off with local liver-bashers to determine what discount canned lager is truly king for the less fortunate. Hey!!!!! Right on the can - ""Return for refund"". Hell yea! I’m gonna get my $1.49 back!!!!"

column3: United States;Stout - Imperial;Fish Brewing Company/Leavenworth Beers;Wow
column4: this held up amazingly after 13 years! Pours thick dark blackish coffee with a great creamy dark caramel colored head. Flavor brings cocoa espresso holding up so well on a full body with minimal oxidation with some settling pleasant caramel notes.

column3: United States;Tripel;Left Hand Brewing Company;From Oct 2006 Poured from 750ml caged and corked bottle(room temp) a cloudy straw gold with a huge head of foam that shrank slowly leaving a solid layer with lots of lacing. The smell is all yeasty and has strong notes of dark fruit like plum and fig as well as lemony citrus. A nice nose overall. The taste has that sweet dark fruit and malt up front but the candi sugar mentioned on the label is what I'm noticing the most...that and a side note of banana that works its way in about midway through and adds some good depth. The finish is a nice mix of sweet and sour that leaves me smacking my mouth in an attempt to keep the flavours going. And..as far as the high abv goes
column4: there's certainly a bit of warming but it's not present in the tasting at all. This is a Tripel that I'd buy again without hesitation! Bottom line: This is a very good effort and worth trying if you see it in a store near you. My hat's off to Left Hand!

column3: United States;Stout;BruRm @ BAR;Cask at Brazen Head. Deep black pour with a thin tan head. The nose is great. Loaded with fresh coffee and a lot of soft malty sweetness. Rich brown sugar along with a decent amount of sweet cocoa on the back of a bright herbal coffee flavour. Not at all vegetal and the coffee is quite expressive. Rich and chewy and fairly unctuous. The texture is soft and chewy with a nice earthy component from the coffee and from the roasted malts. There is a touch of light molasses and chewy toasted grain throughout. A real surprise… one of the better coffee beers I’ve had in quite some time.

column3: United States;Flavored - Fruit;Oasis Brewing Co. & Restaurant;12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a medium red with a small head. Aroma of slight blueberry and malt. Taste of the same with the blueberry coming in on the back end. This light bodied brew could use a bit more blueberry but is still a rather tasty brew.

United States;Flavored - Fruit;Oasis Brewing Co. & Restaurant;Had this beer on 9/7/1998. Color is a deep reddish with good carbonation and head. There is a bit of sediment in the glass. Aroma is a sweet malt scent. Taste is light and crisp with only the slightest hint of blueberry. It starts with a light body that goes down crisp and refreshing. Finish is mild with only a touch of blueberry and a very light bitterness. Overall my rating may be a bit high considering there is not much blueberry flavor for a blueberry brew. But it is one of the easiest drinking and most refreshing beers around. This would be a great beer for a hot summer day.

column12: with a tinny hop finish. good beer overall; let's just reccommend that the brewer save the berries for his pancakes."

column5: rather persistent head. Taste and palate are the beer's weakspot: it seems quite watery with a long lasting aggressive bitterness (=salty?). I'm pretty sure the attribute ""double hopped"" refers to the taste and not the aroma. But one could easily pack much more hop into a beer without creating such a wry bitterness! It's not a beer you'd call a high quality Pils/Lager in the common sense

This beer reminds me a bit of marmite. The flavor is really unpleasant. Medium bodied. Nice lacework. I definately enjoyed the aroma much more than the flavor where a lot of vegetables and metal appear. Strange extremely dry finish with a hint of fish?! I’m really not a fan of Eichhof.

column4: Joe! This pours from 12oz bottle almost a pitch black with a small head of foam that shrinks quickly to a few islands and it has some good lacing. The smell is very sweetish. I'm getting sweet malt and some raosted malt. The taste at first hits me with a lot of sweetness but that is taken over almost immediately by an oat and a roasted malt flavour and...there's something in the taste that is really a sour bitter. It's distracting me from enjoying this brew as much as I should be able to. More sips in and nothing is changing. I *will* say that the finish ends up on a semisweet note and is nice but that distraction that I mentioned is going to knock off some points in the taste department. Too bad.

column3: United States;Pale Ale - English;Arcadia Brewing Company;Poured into an English pint glass
column4: the appearance was a burnt dark copper color with a thin foamy finger’s worth of head. Slowly fell off to leave some stringy lace. The flavor was moderately sweet with a sturdy leafy dryness to slide into the aftertaste and cling in the finish. The feel was almost medium bodied but sat just a tad underneath. Some carbonation was felt but nothing to distract from the style. ABV felt appropriate. Overall

There was some light lacing sticking around the sides of the glass. The smell had a nice blend of sweet caramel malts mixing with a fairly decent earthy / English crisp like atmospheric bittered malts. The taste took those flavors and added an element of nuttiness strolling into the flavoring nicely. On the palate

column4: for sure. The taste on first sip...there's that fruitiness! Sour cherries
column6: and sweet and roasted malt. Dang. Further sips verify the fact that the flavours are working very well together and then there's a touch of bitterness along with a dash of alcohol in the finish. It's *quite* warming and pleasant. Good stuff! PS: I haven't had that many Baltic Porters but this is quite a tasty example. I recommend it! Thanks to Nutbrown for this sample!

column3: United States;Bock - Weizenbock;Copper Crow Beer Company;2005 bottle at the brewpub in July 2008: Pours a transparent dark mahogany with ruby hues and a spotty-lacing froth of light tan head. Pretty decent weizenbock but would be better a little fresher.

column1: Tommyknocker Jack Whacker Wheat Ale;Idaho Springs
column3: United States;Wheat Ale;Tommyknocker Brewery;Poured from bottle into a pint glass Appearance – The beer pours very hazy orange amber color with a small foamy white head. The head fades rather fast leaving a lighter level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass. Smell – The aroma of the brew is heaviest of a wheat smell mixed with a good deal of some lemon and orange. Along with these aromas comes some lighter smells of grain and a little bit of grassy and hay smell. Taste- The taste begins a wheat bread taste mixed with some sweeter flavors of an orange citrus. These flavors create a base taste for the brew
column4: with the orange citrus taste growing slightly stronger as the taste moves forward. Along with the orange
column5: a lemon flavor really kicks its way into the taste. With some grassy and herbal taste coming at the end of the taste
column6: one is left with a wheaty and more sour citrus taste to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel-The body of the brew is rather thick for a brew of only 4.7 % with a carbonation level that is rather low. The thickness is great for the wheat flavors of the brew creating a more chewy feel. A little higher carbonation level would have made the brew slightly more refreshing in nature and matched the sourness slightly better
column7: but overall the feel was pretty good. Overall – A rather decent brew overall. A little bit on the sour side

column3: United States;Pilsener / Pils / Pilsner;Dogwood Brewing Company (GA);Pours out with a pale golden yellow body that is a bit too hazy for a Pilsner. The head was smaller than anticipated and dissipated quickly. The carbonation was medium to low but was helped along by the Pilsner glass I poured it in. Smell was very hoppy with a characteristic whiff of sulfurous and sweet Saaz hops that is spot on for the style. Taste leans quite a bit on the hoppy side. Malts are nicely in the background with mild hints of caramel and honey like sweetness and lemony tart acidity. Mouthfeel is medium and does not feel dumbed down like the mass produced European beers. The aftertaste is a bit harsh but goes well with the raw
column4: down to earth character of this beer. Nicely drinkable local pilsner that would be a great start for a macro convert before moving on to more adventurous stuff.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Terminal Oatmeal Stout;Chicago
column3: United States;Stout - Milk / Sweet;Rock Bottom Chicago;"Night has arrived not just outside but inside my tasting glass. A burnt crema head whispers sweet nothings while she swirls with a light dusting of burnt crema lace. I am immediately enveloped in roasted aromas to set my heart aflutter. Burnt caramels
column4: freshly drawn espresso
column7: and freshly charred wood are followed by prunes nipping playfully in the background. Oats toasted dark brown-black undercut a prominent presence of pine; this is a dry-hop oatmeal stout
column8: after all. The first quaff leaves me reveling in a medium body with a mild watery current. Not quite as filling as I would expect from an oatmeal stout
column10: my tastebuds are already reveling in burnt oats and charred wood. The top of my tongue starts her inevitable drying process as tart prunes playfully strut their stuff. Espresso crema rich with burnt caramels linger long in my breath while underneath is dry
column14: and more espresso. Even though her body is on the thin side
column15: she still enjoys a soft creamy presence thanks to the use of oats. What little presence of hops to be found are in the back of each swallow with pine needles and grass before her espresso takes over once more. Intriguing
column16: though I never felt either aspect of the Terminal Oatmeal Dry-Hop Stout was performing to the best of her ability."

column1: Butte Creek Organic India Pale Ale;Ukiah
column3: United States;IPA;Butte Creek Brewing Company;"It’s always been my policy not to review beers I know are old. However
column4: if I’m not entirely sure – due to an illegible or non-existent freshness code – I’d say it’s fair game. Based on my experience with Butte Creek’s Pale Ale the other day
column5: as well as many years of experience with old beer
column6: I’m inclined to believe this bottle of their IPA is out of code. Had I bought it at a bottle shop or supermarket that would almost be understandable
column7: but I bought this at the brewery’s taproom. Old or not – any beer sold at a brewery’s taproom deserves scrutiny. Let’s just say I’ll bet this beer is pretty good when drank as it’s supposed to be tasted. I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. It appears to have been bottled on 8/28/14 (the code is difficult to decipher) and cost $3 ($0.25 per ounce). Appearance: Dark brownish/orange color; translucent with particulates in suspension. Pours to a two-finger
column9: frothy head which laces and retains surprisingly well. Smell: Mostly sweet golden malt. Some lemon lollipop (usually indicative of old/oxidized beer). Taste: You can always tell an IPA is old because the hop character has really faded (though I’ve never quite understood where the hops go – it’s not like they evaporate in the bottle!). Quite malty for sure – a palette akin to that of an amber ale. Sweet caramel and slight toffee notes
column10: along with yellow lollipop. A mild
column11: but noticeable and consistent bitterness lurks in the background through. It becomes slightly dry and sharp at the apex
column14: or floral flavors and features. For what it’s worth
column15: this is tolerable but not really enjoyable. Drinkability: Butte Creek Organic India Pale Ale weighs in at 6.5% ABV
column16: which is about average for a single IPA these days. Though the palette is uninspired
column17: the actually deliver is passable. Low carbonation provides for a slightly thick/tepid mouthfeel. The hops linger and leave a dry
column18: pasty/starchy aftertaste. I even get some alcohol warmth on the finish
column19: but at least it’s smooth going down. Score: 4/10"

column3: United States;Wheat Ale;Wachusett Brewing Company;Poured from a 12oz. can into a Shock Top glass. The color is a hast yellow/orange with a finger or two foamy white head that stats for a short while but dissolves without a trace on the glass. The smell has some touches of coriander and lemongrass with a wheaty aroma that takes center stage. There is a light malt presence that contributes to the lightness of the nose and gives a small twang. The taste is Wheaty at first before giving up some of that smooth fruit flavor that slides into the margins of this beer bordering the outside edge and keeping things together as things slide into slight punchy end where the hops hide till the very end. This beer is light bodied and is really drinkable with its low ABV and easy drinking feel. The crisp feel adds to dry lip smacking wheat flavor and makes for a great summer drinker.

Roast-derived acidity hampers the body as it compounds the lightly acidic hoppiness. Plasticlike phenols gracelessly exude to compound the hollow and airy center. Forceful hop bitterness gradually emerges and deadens the malt subtleties while clashing with the unrefined gritty roast. Finishes bitterly charred

column3: United States;Porter;Boulder Beer Company;Transfer from BA review on 12-2-12- Poured from bottle into pint glass Appearance- The beer pours a deep brown color with a two finger cream colored head. The head has a great level of retention but fades slowly over time to give a nice level of lacing. Smell – The aroma is heaviest of chocolate and roasted malt aromas. Mixed with these are some sweet aromas of caramel and vanilla as well as a very light coffee smell. Taste – Overall the taste is relatively light. The taste starts out with some roasted malt and a light chocolate flavor. As the taste advances some lighter notes of vanilla come to the tongue. In the end a greater chocolate flavor comes to the tongue and mixes with a lighter coffee flavor to leave a subtle cocoa and roasted coffee flavor on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is below average in terms of thickness and creaminess and the carbonation level is rather average. While the carbonation for the style was nice
column4: the body of the beer was too watery for the style Overall – It had a nice smell and look
column5: but due to the lightness of flavors (which actually were nice) and the very weak body

column15: and it finishes with a nice roasted malt bitterness that tells me I need to take another sip. Great drinkability here and as close to a session brew as a 6%abv brew can get. Damn. Full Sail *is* on top of their game. I just wish that they'd return to Casper so I wouldn't have to trade or go to CO to get some. ;^) Bottom line: Another excellent brew from the gang at Full Sail that lived up to *my* expectations of an American Brown Ale and more specifically

column3: United States;IPA;McNeill's Brewery;"From Aug 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with vermonthiker. Thanks Tom! It's a nice deep amber pour with a 3 finger head of foam(cellar temp). The smell is big on the hops. Floral plays it big here along with some piney notes but intertwined with the hops is a good malty sweetness. I like the nose. The taste is quite bitter. The floral and piney hops make my mouth pucker a bit until some malt sweetness arrives mid palate but doesn't stick around long as the finish gets back on the hoppy and very dry side. Long bitter aftertaste here and it's nice. I'm kind of surprised that this is called an English Style IPA as the malt presence isn't nearly strong enough to hold its own with the hops but...whatever you call it
column4: it's a mighty fine drop and really easy to put away as the abv is relatively low for the style. It has a medium and oily mouthfeel to it
column5: the carbonation is on the low side
column6: and it finishes...err...I already covered that earlier. ;^) Btw
column7: awesome head retention! Bottom line: This is an interesting and tasty and very bitter example of an IPA. It's my first brew from this brewery and I like what they've done here. I've gotta try more East coast IPAs..."

column3: United States;Pale Ale - English;Wasatch Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective);Very solid all-around APA. Poured a perfectly clear copper. Heavy carbonation bubbles. Not much of a head--just a rotating film on top. Nose is very subdued. Mostly just some slight whiffs of malts. Flavor is a true PA. Not overly malty or overly hoppy. Solid balance between the two major ingredients. Hops are a tad sprucey but do not linger on the palate. Some nice tannin flavors too that also come through in the flavor. Medium body but perhaps a bit too carbonated. This beer got me burping. Nice beer.

column2: Belgium;Tripel;Scheldebrouwerij;Purchased at The Malting Pot for €6.90
column3: Zeezuiper is a Belgian Tripel brewed by Brouwerij Schelde. The air reveals clove
column4: coriander
column5: and Belgian yeast on the nose as you drink. The appearance is an orange amber with a low white head. The alcohol content is 8%. The ester of Belgian yeast is rich and spicy to the body with banana following as the beer wanes. Clove adds tone to the comprehension and spices the take. Coriander is wholesome to the yeasty complexion. The dry finish yields the coriander and clove along with a pear character. Orange peel is notable with the coriander. Apricots broadens and provides juiciness with the orange peel. Peaches round out the yeast and orange peel. Caramel is sensible with the peach profile. Barley malt is felt with the yeast dries. Zeezuiper is a remarkable Belgian Tripel. The Belgian yeast
column9: and peach give a unique feel to the complexion. The final product is delicious and infectious to drink. If you are fond of the Belgian style
column10: this is a hallmark to the tradition. As I navigate what local Belgian brews I find
column11: it gets harder to pick and choose which to pick and choose which I want to bring back home to share. Cheers. Prost. Drink for the love of beer. For more beer reviews
column12: visit and like my blog “Drink For the Love of Beer.”

column3: United States;IPA;Russian River Brewing;Aroma is fairly hop forward with a good grapefruit and pine resin aroma along with a bit of a sweeter citrus note and lemon. light cracker malt aroma to balance out the hops. Pours a fairly clear golden orange with a thick white head that has good retention. Good lacing. Flavor is fairly malt forward at the beginning with lots of cracker and a faint sweet caramel note. Mid palate the hops and bitterness hits along with the hop flavor. Hop flavor is grapefruit and pine resin with a light orange note. Bitterness is moderately strong and lingers in the finish with a hint of alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium high carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. Finish is a bit sticky but fairly dry. Overall
column4: a good clean IPA but the style has moved towards a more hop forward profile
column5: especially in the aroma. I also prefer IPAs that are drier than this one.

column3: Australia;Flavored - Other;Masthead Brewery;I have brewed beer with honey and if it is done correctly there is only supposed to be a very faint character of honey as most it goes in the fermentation process. The residual flavour is really then dependant upon the type of honey used and age of the beer. The older it gets the more it becomes mead like and therefore dryer. Having dispensed with the boring bits I then found this one to be an attempt at a light style of beer with an infusion of honey. No surprises but no excitement either. Not the beez knees

column3: Australia;Pale Ale - American / APA;Masthead Brewery;Maybe it's a reaction to rating so many below average beers lately but I quite liked this one. Pours an attractive gold amber crystal clear under a medium size and lasting pale yellow head and generates some remanent lacing. Medium floral honey sweet nectar with hint of perfumed soap aroma. Thinnish low carb but stii quite satisfying body. Medium strength dry floral bitter hop start. Slightly sweeter malt middle back to bitter finish and that dry floral bitter again in the aftertaste.

column3: United States;Kölsch / Kölsch-Style;Ross Valley Brewing Company;Pours a hazy golden color with a tinge of orange. Lots of sediment in the bottle. Aroma is a little grainy. Very little carbonation. Tastes like an american wheat with not much flavor.
United States;Kölsch / Kölsch-Style;Ross Valley Brewing Company;"(22 oz bottles) This is a very interesting little experiment I'm doing here. I visited the Ross Valley brewery a few months ago
column4: and I was honored to have a private tasting with the head brewer
column5: Melissa. When I told her I bought a bottle of the Kölsch Golden Ale at BevMo in San Diego
column6: she was shocked because the beer wasn't supposed to be distributed that far
column7: and was worried about proper handling. She gave me a bottle from her storeroom and asked me to do a direct comparison with the bottle I bought at BevMo
column9: I'm not a big Kölsch fan
column10: we should probably get that out of the way right first off. Anyway
column11: the two bottles are extraordinarily different. The BevMo bottle is a very boring and lifeless beer. It pours with almost no head
column12: and though there is some sediment in the bottle
column13: it still pours quite clear. The beer basically has no aroma
column14: it has a faint smell of ""beer"" and that's it. The flavor is very thin with almost no maltiness to speak of
column15: and even the hops seems very mild with only a gentle bitterness. And the palate is very thin and watery. In a nutshell
column16: it tastes like a light beer.Now then
column17: onto the bottle Melissa gave to me. Holy shit
column19: there is a LOT of chunky sediment in the bottom of the bottle
column20: much more than the BevMo bottle
column21: and I don't remember ever having a Kölsch with sediment in the bottle before. While this Kölsch is not as crisp as the style usually is
column22: the flavor is quite interesting. It has a lightly sweet and bready maltiness that is totally absent in the BevMo bottle
column23: a fair amount of citrus flavor
column24: and is mildly bitter. It seems quite a bit less hoppy than the style dictates
column25: but still significantly moreso than the BevMo bottle. I usually don't detect salty flavors in beers
column26: but the saltiness in this one seems to stand out to me. It has a heavier mouthfeel than is typical for the style with some lingering sweetness rather than crisp acidity. The nose is very bready and lemony. On the first pour
column27: it's pale yellow in color and fairly cloudy from the sediment
column28: but when finish the first glass and empty the bottle in the glass on that second pour
column30: the color of the beer is now a dark golden. Very carbonated pour produces a huge snow white head that is comprised mostly of large bubbles. The large head dissipates quickly
column32: maintains a half-inch layer until there is no more beer left. Some patchy globs of lacing are left behind.So then
column33: what accounts for the huge difference between these two bottles? Freshness? Proper storage? All the extra sediment? Whatever the reason
column34: if you have this Kölsch and don't like it
column35: perhaps you should make the hike out to the brewery (kind of tough to find) and get a bottle from the brewery. And seek out Melissa

column3: United States;Kölsch / Kölsch-Style;Ross Valley Brewing Company;The after its emancipation from the 22 ounce brown bottle pours a smoggy light lemon yellow color with a modest bright white head that dissipates rather quickly leaving behind a thin coating of lace to obscure the glass. Nose is citrus like in its crispness

column3: United States;Kölsch / Kölsch-Style;Ross Valley Brewing Company;Bottled Sparklingly clear pale gold color. Poured a small creamy white head that diminished after 2 minutes to a thin
column4: fairly long lasting layer with very little lacing. Light malt aroma layered with a fairly present citrusy hop nose and a subtle vinous acidity. Flavor had an assertive hop bitterness start to finish. Started with a crisp and malty off dry character
column5: which followed through to mid-palate where a subtly vinous acidity emerged. Finish was dry with lingering hop bitterness. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a lively carbonation. Crisply refreshing session brew with an assertive bitterness that holds your palate’s attention. Perfect for warm and sultry summer days when your palate may crave something easier and less complex.

column3: United States;Porter;Berkshire Brewing Company;22 ounce bomber As far as freebies go you could choose something far worse than this middle of the road porter. Even at its full price (about $4.99) it is a bargain for a drinkable release from what seems to be a reliably solid regional brewery. When I pass through Massachusetts again perhaps I'll see what they have that's new. Aroma / Appearance - The fluid black base melts into the glass with a soft mocha head that slowly ebbs. Ashy cigarette butts fill the air along with roasted chestnuts. The profile gets the spirit of a porter but not the best aspects. Flavor / Palate - Smoky blueberries meld with cool ash. The dry roasted finish sticks to the palate. A basic and effective porter gets the job done without much fanfare. If you are looking for a textbook example of the style that is as close to average as they come buy a bottle.
